OK, I paused at Henry. He was infected by analogy (ok for kindergarteners) --- with the "ball rolling down inclined plane with friction" classic lab. Wrong analogy! Obviously in that case GPE gets traded for both LKE and RKE. But my physics brain told me this was not the case for the bullet + block. In the bullet + block we have all three conservation laws always holding, since (approximately) no heat loss, no ext. force, no ext. torque. So linear p has to be roughly conserved (caveats below). The caveat is I had to assume the bullet gets lodged in the block, this was not clear in your vdo!!! grrr. Also the difference in sonic + heat loss (and wood splinter loss) energy is roughly the same in both cases, i.e., negligible for the height approximate calculation. Anyhooo, with those assumptions, the bullet + block never lose much linear p nor gain any extra rotational L , so the initial angular momentum from the centre of mass frame is conserved, so the spinning block was already inherent in the side angle attack of the bullet. Case closed for conservation of p and L . The block has to rise about the exact same height.
"Ahhh," you say to me, "where did the extra energy come from to rotate the block so damn fast, if the GPE gain was the same huh? Can you answer that smarty pants?" And I can surely answer you, it came from the difference in deformation damage to the block. From the side hit case the block does not take the full brunt of the bullet, it's like a pre-Awoken Neo, it dodges the bullet slightly, the bullet still wedges in, but cannot do as much kinetic damage. I mean, go ahead, you try to wedge a bullet in an oak or pine wooden block with your hand... it ain't so easy without a direct centre hit.
So this is an inelastic collision problem, not a GPE <--> RKE trade-off puzzle.
How did I do Mum?
Also, imagine the bullet hitting a steel block versus a marshmallow or jello block of the same mass... bullet still wedge in... which block will shoot up higher? The steel block. Far more kinetic deformation damage done to the marshmallow, it'll have to be an awfully long marshmallow to keep the bullet still wedged in it, the bullet will make an extremely long core, perhaps a 100m??? Of course, it is harder by hand to dent a steel block, but that's a "lever" problem. Pack all the energy you need to core a 100m long marshmallow with a long piece of dowel all at once into a steel block and the steel block will dent a tad, comparatively though a lot less deformation damage. (Actually, I'd like to see this comparison, my instinct could be wrong, maybe coring a 100m long marshmallow is easy, and ignoring air friction the marshmallow might shoot up higher? You have to account for time (power) though, coring a 100m long marshmallow in a millisecond is awfully hard.)

A clarification. The velocity V calculated previously is the initial velocity of the center of the block. After the bullet lodges in the block the center of mass of the "block plus bullet" does have a velocity Vc=mv/(M+m) for all values of the impact distance "b", so this center of mass does rise to the same height. However. the center of the spinning block orbits about the center of mass of the "block plus bullet" and so rises above it and sinks below it. Thus the maximum height of the center of the block depends on the phase of the rotation at the point at which the combined center of mass is at its maximum height. This is all somewhat pedantic and for the masses involved the effect is too small to observe, but for m>M these effects would not be negligible.

This is a well known problem, as it is similar to a ball hitting a bat or tennis racquet, see Rod Cross "Impact of a ball with a rigid rod" Eur. J Phys 41 (2020) 035001. In the case of the bullet becoming embedded in the block mechanical energy is not conserved. However both angular and linear momentum are conserved and the final velocity of the bullet is the same as that of its location in the block. Note that due to the rotational motion of the block this velocity is not the same as that of the center of mass, except for b=0. For the bullet of mass m and velocity v hitting the stationary block of mass M and sides a and c at a distance b from the center of mass the resulting velocity of the center of mass of the block is V=mv/[m(1+b^2/k^2)+M] where the gyradius of the block is given by k^2=(a^2+c^2)/12. For b=0 this is V=m/(m+M) which is the largest value of V. In the experiment m<<M and so the resulting velocities are almost the same, but this is not the case when the masses m and M are the same.

I'm a bit late here, but the problem Derek and Destin have is a faulty assumption. It makes no sense how only one block can be rotating if both systems have the same rotational momentum/energy, but in fact, the two systems never had identical rotational energy/momentum. When you realize this, the paradox disappears.

As shown (in the explanation video), it is easy to see that the linear momentum is identical in both cases, and that alone can explain the identical height (within experimental tolerance). With the first system, there is no angular momentum, as the system's center of mass is inline with the centers of gravity of the block and bullet, and the bullet's velocity is along that same line: angular momentum is zero.

When the bullet is fired off-center, the system is now different, and it is a mistake to assume the angular momentum is again zero. Now, the system center of mass is still in-between the block and bullet (but no longer directly below the block or above the bullet, it is off to the side), and it travels upward at a proportion of the velocity the bullet does (the CoM velocity is identical to the first case). But now the bullet velocity and block velocity (relative to the system center of mass) is not in-line with the system center of mass, therefore the starting angular momentum is not zero. This is the crucial difference from before. When the bullet hits the block, it transfers the system rotational momentum to the block and we get rotation, no laws are broken.

I guessed right, and here's my reasoning. (1) I knew it was going to be an unexpected answer, or you wouldn't have made this video. :-) (2) Think about it: In inelastic collisions (such is these), both linear and angular momentum are conserved, but kinetic energy is NOT. Conservation of linear momentum alone predicts that the blocks will reach the same height. Angular momentum is also conserved in that the spinning block has the exact same angular momentum as the bullet-block system just prior to collision. But the spinning block clearly shows more kinetic energy, so how can it go as high? In both cases (as in all inelastic collisions) kinetic energy is lost to heat. But in the second case, the bullet is not slowed down as much (it's moving much faster in the spinning block), so less energy is lost to heat, and remains as kinetic energy. Bottom line, conservation of momentum (and gravity, of course) is what determines the final height in both cases.

I'm a little surprised that Destin (Smarter Every Day) didn't see this immediately. But I have to admit, my first intuition was wrong as well.

When the bullet strikes the block off-center, the block begins to spin.  As the block begins to spin, the block acts as a lever and the nail pushes downward against the plexiglass stand.  The plexiglass structure sits on solid ground, so as the nail pushes downward against it, the effective result is the nail is helping to launch the block upward (just as anything that gives the earth a downward shove will itself experience an upward acceleration). Hence the spinning block will reach about the same height as the non-spinning block, even though some energy is used toward spin acceleration instead of a directly-upward acceleration.  To prove my theory, you can do the experiment again, removing the plexiglass stand at the exact moment of bullet contact (I'm not sure how this could be done).  Or more easily you can suspend the block using a squishy support structure instead of the rigid plexiglass. If you do this the result will be much different, and the spinning block will not go as high as the non-spinning block.

Okay so there's a few things to consider here. The block is balanced on it's centroid, meaning that being shot there provides the most resistance to an upward velocity. If the block is shot to the side of it's centroid, then much more vertical velocity will be imparted on the side that was shot. This means that that side will begin to accelerate upwards faster and pull the other side along with it. Because you've got a greater force pulling the block upwards, the other half of the block will also accelerate upwards faster.

Here's my take:
In both cases KE is split into 3 parts:
1. One transferred sideways from the bullet  to the wood block, much like a wedge (look it up on wikipedia), dissipating.
2. KE inparted to the block, hence block momentum.
3. Remainder of bullet KE as it travels inside the block.
But how much of each in each case?
Well, my intuition says that (2) take precedence over the others, so as long as block inertia (or any other resistance force) allows, the bullet pushes the block, i.e. elastic collision. Due to inertia and velocity differences, inelastic collision takes over, the bullet dissipating further energy (3) into the block (1).
Amount of (3) has to do with materials, shape i.e. invariant in both cases.
Case 1: greater resistance -- less of (2), more of (1).
Case 2: remember allows ? same amount of "allowing" but over a greater distance (consider the elevated shot side due to rotation)

So my prediction: same height, same penetration, same inside bullet trajectory, different "wound" profiles.

A constant annoyance for me in textbooks/notes/lectures etc is that when these Newtonian mechanics questions are posed or answered, the System is never explicitly defined or answered ( even in solutions). If the system is the bullet and block, momentum is not conserved due to Gravity (an external force) acting on it. If the Earth (and the gun rigidly attached to it) is included, then momentum is conserved. Of course energy equations can't be used due to unknown transfer into heat/sound.

I follow what you're saying, but I don't think it'll work, though it's hard to explain in so few words.  It has to do with energy being proportionate with the square of the velocity. E.g., if you had half your block move twice as fast, and stop the other half entirely, the total energy would be double what you'd expect, i.e., (1/2) * m * v^2 is half of [(1/2) * (m/2) * (0*v)^2] + [(1/2) * (m/2) * (2*v)^2]. Sometimes it is useful to look at what isn't happening.  If this were an inelastic collision, we can determine the expected final height of the block.  KE=1/2MV^2  (2.3g bullet, 405 m/s -- rough #s).  PE = mgh (m=220g).  Solving for h, we get h=175m.  In other words, There is *a lot* (sorry, engineering term) of energy "lost" in the inelastic collision.  Some goes towards spinning, some towards penetration.  Force vectors, impulse, momentum etc. might explain why they are the same height.

Angular momentum is a pseudovector, and it has different units from momentum.  It is conserved, just like momentum is, but the two can't be traded for each other.  The angular momentum of the entire system (i.e., block + bullet) relative to the center of mass of the system is the same before and after the collision. In the first case, the bullet is traveling towards the center of mass, so there's no angular momentum to worry about.

Not really, both - angular momentum and linear momentum are vector quantities. In the spinning case the bullet, before it hits the block, only has angular momentum from the perspective of the block. I think the thing that's messing people up being too concerned with the energy and/or the angular momentum of the system, but neither of those are relevant.  The only thing you need to worry about is momentum, and the fact that it must be conserved.  Momentum and angular momentum are not the same things, and they can't be converted to one another.  Momentum is a vector quantity, meaning direction is important.  A spinning block doesn't have momentum; half is going one way [cont'd]

It is all about principle of force superposition. The force not pointing to the center of gravity can be replaced by same force with same direction pointing toward the center of the mass and rotational moment. So the force pushing the block upwards is in both cases the same => the block will go to the same height. The additional energy of the rotation is in first case used to penetrate the block deeper (and of course the more heat energy, but i think it is a small difference in temperature).

Think about using your legs to jump up in the air, compared to using the same force to spin yourself on a low-friction merry-go-round. You'll get maybe 18-24 inches in the air before gravity pulls you down, but you'll go a lot further on the merry-go-round because you're only decelerated by friction. So we think the spinning block has a lot more "energy" but that rotational momentum was not necessarily a big part of the original momentum...we just notice it more because it keeps spinning.

I agree with #2, that momentum is conserved. Before the impact, the bullet has linear momentum and the block has none. After the impact, the block-plus-bullet should have the same momentum. For the center impact, it's all linear, but for the off-center impact, it's a combination of linear and angular. I am guessing that most is linear, but we notice the angular acceleration more because nothing is slowing it down--whereas the linear acceleration is immediately countered by gravity.

Think of it as three energy recipients from the bullet's kinetic energy.

A. Height-energy (HE)
B. Rotational-energy (RE)
C. Deformation-Energy (DE) [I'm going to include the extra heat in the wood block in this]

The off-center block trades DE for more RE. The reason the off-center block gets less DE is because it is struck off center which means it can't put up as much resistance to the bullet, so it is not penetrated as deeply.

HE stays close to the same (can't be sure if it's identical)
Oh, and the wooden block can't start with a lower vertical speed, as the momentum of the bullet and the momentum of the block+bullet have to be the same.

I think that in the first block more heat was generated initially through friction as the difference in speed of the bullet and the part of the block being penetrated was greater. In the second block the 'extra' kinetic energy was just the energy that had not yet been converted to heat energy.

If the block were held firmly in place, the bullet would go deeper still; but because the block is free to move some of the energy goes into moving the block and what is left goes into the penetration. If the block can also rotate, even more of the energy of the bullet can go into making it move (translation PLUS rotation) so even less is left for it to penetrate the wood.

Kinetic energy = 1/2mv^2, but it is important to note that velocity is a vector. Hence, any corner of the rectangle that was spinning one way will have a counterpart in its opposite corner which moves at exactly the same speed but opposite direction. Therefore there is no NET rotational energy gain by the system, and work is only done in raising the block's center of gravity, the same as block 1.

The amount of energy delivered by the bulled to the system bullet+block is spent on the rotation and translation in the gravity field.
Therefore if there is no rotation, more energy is available for translation. The block goes higher.

But, the amount of energy spent on rotation is so small compared to the total energy, that you'd need lots of repeats, precise measuring (laser) and a statistical approach to see that.

Momentum is always conserved during collisions, but kinetic energy is only conserved in a perfectly elastic collision. More energy is lost to the wood's compression in the straight shot one, a little less in the spinning one, the rest of the spinning one's energy is put into it spinning. However, in both cases, the momentum in the vertical direction is conserved.

The difference between the two is the depth of the bullet in the block of wood. 

The bullet goes further into the the non spinning block (center shot)  and ends up at a height H. 

The Bullet does not go into the block as far because it is imparting angular momentum into the block which results in the spin.

Even though the height is the same, the depth of the bullet into the block is what is different between the two.

Linear momentum is conserved in both systems and this is why both blocks reached the same height.  All upward linear momentum is imparted as the bullet enters the blocks and the blocks speed off at the same momentum as the original bullet.
The moment of inertia in the first system imparts resistance to the upwards movement of the bullet, hence lost total kinetic energy.  In the second system, the linear momentum of the bullet is converted into angular momentum, therefore less energy is lost.

Same height:

Energy is not conserved in inelastic collisions, thus, the two situations don't need to have the same final mechanical energy. Momentum, however, is. In all collisions, both linear and angular momentum is conserved. Therefore, as both bullets have the same linear momentum at the start, both block bullet systems have the same linear momentum and thus will have the same linear speed about the center of mass after the collision. Thus, they will attain the same height of their CoM.
